A. BACKGROUND
1. Country Background. Political instability in Haiti has been recurrent over the last two decades. After a return to constitutional order in 1994, an unresolved institutional crisis, and contested elections in 2000 compounded political uncertainties and led to a reduction in foreign assistance. Following these events, state institutions weakened and poor governance practices multiplied. This culminated in another political crisis in early 2004, and on February 29,2004, President Aristide resigned and left the country. In conformity with the Constitution, Mr.Boniface Alexandre, President of the Supreme Court of Appeal, took office as the interim president. That evening, the UnitedNations Security Council approved Resolution 1529 authorizing the immediate deployment of a Multinational InterimForce to help maintain order inHaiti. Followinga consultative process, Mr.Latortue was then designated as interim Prime Minister and established a government on March 17,2004. On April 30,2004, the United Nations Security Council created the UnitedNations Stabilization Mission in Haiti.
2. After the creation of the transitional government, an InterimCooperation Framework (ICF) was preparedunder the leadership o f the government with the support of the donor community. It represents a conscious effort to break with the past, to frame external assistance on the basis of ajoint identification of the needs, and to realistically design programs for the transition period (2004-2006). The structure for the formulation and coordination of the ICF was based on three pillars: 1) an Inter-Ministerial Committee comprising four ministries under the coordination o f the Ministry of Planning, Environment and External Cooperation; 2) a Steering Committee, made up of representatives from the government and the donors, responsible for the technical aspects of governance, and 3) ten thematic groups involving national and international experts from the public and private sectors, civil society, and the international community. One of these thematic groups oversees the protection and rehabilitation of the environment.
3. The Thematic Environmental Group (Groupe ThkmatiqueEnvironnement or GTE) examines environmental issues and proposes strategies to address them. Since its inception, the GTE has highlighted the catastrophic proportions of environmental degradation in Haiti and the link to the welfare of the population and poverty reduction efforts. Three priority interventions involving environmental management have been outlined: (i) reduction of pressure on wood resources; (ii) improved environmental resource management and planning; and (iii) sustainable and integrateddisaster risk management through the implementation of the National Risk and Disaster Management Plan (Plan National de Gestion des Risques et Dkssastres or PNGRD). Given the current state of institutional preparedness, considerable institutional strengthening and improvement of Haiti's legal and institutional framework are required to improve risk reduction efforts, as well as disaster preparedness and emergency response. The proposed
6  project focuses heavily on improving the country's capacity to manage the risk of disasters.
4. Natural Hazards and Disasters in Haiti. Haiti is one of the Caribbean countries most affected by natural disasters (hurricanes, floods, droughts, earthquakes, etc.). The island of Hispaniola lies inthe middle of the hurricane belt and i s subject to severe storms from June to October. The effects of tropical storms and hurricanes include wind damage, flooding, landslides and coastal surges. These effects are exacerbated by environmental degradation, since only about 3.2% of Haiti's natural forest remains. Extensive deforestation and the presence of settlements in low areas and infloodplains of rivers are key factors in the intensity of the destruction. Indeed, under the present conditions, every segment of the Haitian population i s vulnerable to adverse natural events. Taking into account the percentage of the population living under the poverty line and the fact that the poorest groups are always the worst affected, it is evident that the majority of the Haitian population i s at risk.
5. Besides the hydro-meteorological hazards, Haitihas suffered from serious earthquakes inthe past. The country i s located in a seismically active zone and according to records kept since the 16thcentury, the Island o f Hispaniola has had at least one major earthquake every century. A major earthquake in 1751destroyed Port-au-Prince, earthquakes in 1842 and 1904 destroyed Cap Haitien (4,000 fatalities in 1842; 5,000 in 1904), and there was an 8.1 magnitude earthquake in 1946 in the northeastern Dominican Republic which was followed by a tsunami inthe Nagua area (5,000 fatalities). The very highpopulation density (upto 40,000 per km2inPort-au-Prince), the largenumber of informal structures in slum areas, the weak infrastructure and the lack o f response capabilities suggest that another major earthquake would have disastrous consequences. The seismological pattern of the faults and studies funded by the UnitedNations Development Program (UNDP), show that there i s an important energy accumulationthat could trigger a major earthquake anytime.
6. Haiti's high vulnerability to natural disasters stems also from highlevels of poverty, weak infrastructure, a degraded environment, and a history o f ineffective governments with serious fiscal problems. Given the poor state o f economic infrastructure and lack of preparedness, disasters of lesser magnitude occurring on a frequent basis also cause immeasurable impacts on the population and on economic assets. Vulnerability reduction and disaster management have received very limited attention from past governments. The proposedproject i s intended to lay the foundation for improving this situation.
7. The most recent serious disaster inHaiti occurred on September 18,2004 when torrential rain coming with the Tropical Storm Jeanne caused flash floods affecting the entire region between Cap Haitien and Port-de-Paix in the North and Gonaives in the West. The rain caused not only flash floods but also mudslides cutting the access roads to many villages for days. These floods affected an estimated population of 300,000, destroying approximately 4,500 houses and claiming more than 3,000 lives. The impact of this disaster on Haiti has been especially harsh as the country was still recovering from
7  the floods o f May 2004 when seventeenhours of continuous rain inthe southeastern province of Haiti caused flash floods and landslides inthe areas of Belle-Anse and Fonds Verrettes. These floods affected more than 100,000 people with more than 2,000 dwellings destroyed and 1,000 deaths.
8. Similarities between the floods of May and September are striking. In both cases, the heavy rainfall drove flash flooding and extensive debris flows over extended regions. Swollen rivers and debris cut off many of the roads traversing the affected areas along the base of the mountains. As the floodwaters flowed into the relatively flatter lands and broader channels of the alluvial plain below, they spread out, wiping out riverside settlements. The disasters illustrate the continuumbetween severe storms, flooding and landslides, where debris-laden floodwaters modify the landscape. Major floods of this type are now near-annual events inHaiti and the Dominican Republic and can be expected to increase in the future, leading to increased vulnerability.

10. Disaster Management Capacity. The national civil protection structure i s in charge of risk and disaster management activities inHaiti. The system has several coordination levels and includes the following 10ministries and agencies: the Ministry of Interior and Local Government; the Ministry of Public Health and Population; the Ministry of Public Works, Transport and Communication; the Ministry of Agriculture,
8  Natural Resources and Rural Development; the Ministry of Environment; the Ministry of Planning and External Cooperation; the Ministry of Social Affairs; the Ministry of Justice and Public Security; the Ministry of National Education, Youth and Sport; and, the Haitian Red Cross. The system i s headedby the National Risk and Disaster Management Committee (Comite'National de Gestion des Risques et des De'sastres,or CNGRD), which is composed of the respective ministers and the president of the Haitian Red Cross and leadb y the Ministry of Interior. The Directorate of Civil Protection (DPC) supports the Ministry of Interior inthis function.
11. A second level of coordination i s at the technical and executive level where executives of ministries and agencies meet to form the Permanent Secretariat o f Riskand Disaster Management (Secre'tariatPermanent de Gestion des Risques et des De'sastres,or SPGRD). The SPGRD is ledby the General Directorate of the Ministry of Interior and i s divided into two branches: a disaster management branch composed of the Emergency Operation Center (EOC); and a risk management branch, composed of thematic and sectoral committees, which oversees permanent activities.
12. To implement on a daily basis the coordination of risk and disaster management activities, the Pre-Disaster Organization (Organisation Pre-De'sastre,or OPDES) was established in 1983, first under the Ministry o f Health and later under the Ministry of the Interior. Since the OPDES focused on preparedness without much attention to risk reduction, in 1997 the government established the Directorate of Civil Protection, with a mandate for risk reduction, response andrecovery; and the OPDES ceasedto function. After Hurricane Georges in 1998, the Ministry of Interior developed the PNGRD to guide the activities of the DPC and give it a legal framework. Under the transitional government established inFebruary 2004, disaster management has been assigned directly to the DPC. The government intends to increase the status and capacity of the DPC by transforming it into a General Directorate, which would provide it with increased autonomy and scope for action. The organization's role is expected to reach beyond providing disaster assistanceby setting up an active program to plan for and mitigate the impact of adverse natural events. DPC will establish a national risk reduction strategy; advise and support the Ministry o f Interior and the CNGRDinits coordinating position and; supervise the risk mitigation and disaster preparedness activities carried through the different ministries and organizations. Inaddition, the government intends to appoint Disaster Management Coordinators at the departmental level.
13. Ongoing efforts. The transitional government has expressed its intentions by committing to a sound strategy, clear goals, and an implementation time frame, developed during the ICF. The three main activity components and their goals include: (i) institutional reinforcement involving: preparation for the upcoming hurricane season, a functioning operational emergency operation center, a training center, three functional thematic committees (public awareness, buildingnorms, and land-use planning), risk and disaster management units within concerned ministries, and a validated legal framework for the DPC and the SPGRD; (ii) an information systemfor risk identification and monitoring involving: an awarenessprogram for the media and decision makers, studies about the seismic risk, seismic mapping, seismic activity monitoring system, and the
9  development of an operational disaster data base, national communication system, and detailed risk mapping of three departments, as well as micro zoning of Port-au-Prince; (iii) riskmanagementincluding:70operationalcivilprotectionlocalcommittees local and early warning systems to be installed inthe South and Artibonite departments,
14. Riskand disaster management inHaiti also received special interest from the international community after Hurricane Georges in 1998 with the investment by the UNDP,UnitedStatesAgency for InternationalDevelopment (USAID), andother agencies. Their contribution helped develop the National Plan for Risk and Disaster Management and the National Response Plan, and establish the first EOC. Many Non-Governmental Organizations (NGO) have also worked on the creation of local civil protectioddisaster response committees, and some have taken part inbasic risk reduction activities. In operational support and technical assistance, the UNDPi s the most prominent agency currently active inHaiti. The UNDPrisk and disaster management unit has been providing technical assistanceto the DPC since 1998 and focuses on: (i) capacity building; (ii)developing response and preparedness plans; (iii) strengthening preparedness; and (iv) establishing a national training center. Their presence and collaboration with the DPC i s a great asset to the project.
B. IDA RESPONSESTRATEGY
15. The Emergency Recovery and Disaster Management Project (ERDMP) has been prepared within the ICF strategy explained above in order to provide assistance for the rehabilitation of areas affected b y the recent floods and to begin to address deficiencies in the National System for Disaster Risk Management (SystdmeNational de Gestion des Risques et des Dkssastres). International Development Association (IDA) missions have worked with the DPC, inclose collaboration with the UNDP, The Inter-American Development Bank (IADB), and the Organization of American States (OAS) to help define the scope of intervention and institutional improvements necessary. They have also defined the support necessary to enable the DPC to begin to play a more meaningful role inrisk and disaster management, and to activate and strengthen the national system.
16. The project will follow two separate initiatives currently being implemented underthe LICUS (Low Income Countries Under Stress) TrustFundof the World Bank Group. These initiatives provide support to strengthen the capacity for emergency recovery as well as risk and disaster management activities until the ERDMPi s fully operational. The first LICUS initiative, worth US$l million, involves measures to establish rehabilitation plans and beginemergency interventions (infrastructure and social support) to help the population recover from the May 23 floods. Support will also be provided for institutional strengthening in disaster management at the national level, with a focus on boosting technical, management, and administrative capacity in the DPC. The LICUS initiative also assesses the need for capacity buildingin risk and disaster management, which will lead to the development of a training program to assist government and NGO staff at the national and regional levels.
10  17. The second LICUS initiative, also for US$1 million, will support short-term, labor-intensive employment in environmental works, by channeling funds to communities through NGOs. It will reinforce government capacity at the national and local levels to use contractual arrangements to manage labor-intensive, small-scale development projects. This funding will benefit some 40,000 members of poor families inrural and urban areas. Capacity of the national structure for disaster riskmitigation is expected to be strengthened by this effort. Depending on the success of this initiative, it could be expanded to implement part of the small-scale environmental mitigation works to be carried out under this proposed project.
18. The proposedproject will build on the LICUS initiatives. It will finance identified works inFonds Verrettes, Belle-Anse, and the region affectedby the floods of September 2004, in addition to supporting activities under all three components of the government's ICF strategy. The project will strengthen the management and administrative systems inthe DPC and finance technical training for the DPC and other agencies involved in disaster risk management. It will also support the retrofitting of an emergency operation center, the establishment of a training center, and will finance the purchase of equipment for national and regional emergency operation centers. Technical support will assist inupdating the National Response Plan, establishing emergency funds, and increasing the national emergency response capacity. The project will also support technical studies, such as the preparationof an environmental assessment study for natural disaster vulnerability, public awareness campaigns, and establishing building norms for public buildings. Finally, almost 50 percent of the fundingwill be used for local risk management to help communities identify and reduce risks.
C. PROJECT OBJECTIVES
19. The development objective of the proposed project will be:
(a) to support the rehabilitation of the areas affectedby the recent adverse natural disasters; (b) to strengthen the country's capacity to manage naturaldisaster risks andbetter respond to emergencies resulting from adverse natural events; and (c) to reduce the vulnerability o f communities through risk identification and risk mitigation activities.
20. These objectives are consistent with one o f the focal points o f the Transitional Support Strategy (TSS) that outlines IDA'Sstrategy for Haiti over the next 24 months (FY05 and FY06). The TSS explicitly incorporates the activities already submitted to the LICUS Trust Fund, including the proposed disaster reconstruction and mitigation initiatives mentioned above (paragraphs 16-17). The TSS, being presented to the Board together with this proposed operation, also includes in the lending program the proposed Emergency Recovery and Disaster Management Project for US$12 million equivalent.
11  21. The objectives are also consistent with the overall priorities on environmental management within the ICF. The longer term objectives of the Environment Thematic Group, in which IDA i s an active participant, include the development of sustainable strategies to reverse resource degradation by introducing sustainable watershed management, reforestation and measuresto reduce the impact of climatic hazards.
22. The outcome indicators to be monitored during the course of the project include:
(a) satisfactory planning and completion of a rehabilitation scheme for affected settlements in the regions of Belle-Anse, Fonds Verrettes, and Gonaives; (b) capacity established within the DPCto prepare for, and respond to, natural disaster events which includes: (i) a validated legal framework;(ii) stronger management systems; (iii) improved technical capacity; and (iv) an operational National Response Plan; (c) functioning disaster committees in at least 70 communes and the successful implementation of riskprevention and reduction measures invulnerable communities.
D. PROJECT DESCRIPTION
23. The IDA operation will be implementedover a period of approximately four years and will finance the following components:
Component 1-Reconstructionand Risk Reduction inthe Areas Recently Affected by Floods (US$2.5 million equivalent)
24. The Government of Haiti (GOH) is preparing a recovery plan to support the reconstructionof the areas affected b y recent floods with the assistance of the UNDP. The proposed allocation will be used in accordance with the plan and the activities implementedwith the LICUS funds, and will assist small rehabilitation activities implemented by the affectedcommunities through the financing of buildingmaterials, etc.
Component 2 - Institutional Strengthening for the Directorate of Civil Protection (DPC) and the Permanent Secretariat for Risk and Disaster Management (SPGRD) (US$3.5 million equivalent)
25. Institutional and Technical Support. The project will support the DPC and the SPGRD in the implementation of the PNGRD, including: (i) provision of institutional the and technical support for the creation o f a training and documentation center and risk management units within key ministries; and three thematic committees under the SPGRD including public awareness, building norms, and land use planning; (ii) the revision and validation of the National Response Plan and the development o f related emergency procedures and protocols; (iii) the creation, training, and equipping of disaster assessment and disaster
12  intervention teams within DPC and key ministries; and (iv) the realization of simulation exercises at local and regional scale.
26. Technical Studies. The establishment of the SPGRD thematic committees will leadto the implementation of three main technical studies. First, the public awareness thematic committee will supervise the design and implementation of a public awareness program directed towards both the general public, and decision makers, to explain disaster management efforts to a larger audience. Second, the buildingnorms thematic committee will coordinate technical studies and workshops to support the establishment of buildingnorms that take natural hazards into account. The initiative will be implemented in close collaboration with the Ministry of Public Works and will aim at establishing norms from the construction of public buildings and donor funded projects. Finally, the project will finance an environmental assessment study for natural disaster vulnerability, envisioned to connect the efforts of natural resource management to those of planning and risk reduction. This study will be implemented incoordination with the land use planning committee and inclose collaboration with the Ministry of Agriculture, Natural Resources and Rural Development.
27. Rehabilitation of the Emergency Operation Center(E0C)of the DPC. To enable the efficient functioning of the DPC and SPGRD intimes of crisis, the project will assist the retrofitting of the national Emergency Operations Center and the purchase of the necessary equipment to make it operational. The project will also support the retrofitting of regional EOCs ineach department as well as the installation of a national communication system to coordinate operations between the national and departmental levels.
28. Strengthening Management Systems within DPC. To better fulfill its functions, the DPC i s to become a General Directorate within this calendar year. The project will strengthen the DPC with a new accounting system to monitor the funds it disburses and an updated inventory system to track its resources. The project will also reinforce management, administrative and technical capacity within the DPC and the SPGRD by training its staff at the national and departmental levels. Finally, the DPC's planning capacity will be strengthened b y supporting institutional development plans. In conjunction to the UNDPeffort to define the legal structure of the DPC, the project will also support the establishment of emergency fundingprocedures.
Component 3 - Local Risk Management (US$5.5 million equivalent)
29. Almost 50 percent of the project funds will be usedfor development and mitigation activities at the local level in areas o f highvulnerability to natural disasters. This component will help DPC create or reactivate local emergency committees and train them inrisk and disaster management. These committees, incoordination with community councils, will prepare local risk and vulnerability maps and identify risk reduction activities (early warning systems, retention walls, terracing, drainage works, pilot-reforestation projects, shelter retrofitting, etc.) that the project will finance. Some 70 local committees are expected to be created or reactivated, 50 percent of which will be
13  inurban or peri-urban areas. Most activities under this component will be implemented usingCommunity Driven Development (CDD), which is already beingused on a pilot basis intwo Bank-supportedactivities inHaiti (CDD Pilot Project in Haiti - TF051116; and LICUS for Labor IntensiveBasic InfrastructureRehabilitation Pilot Project - TF053366). A national-level Government agency (PL 480 Management Office) will coordinate the efforts on behalf of the DPC with the DPC directly involved in strategy formulation and supervision. Several NGOs selected according to shared criteria between IDA and the DPC will be responsible for implementation at the local level.

30. Disaster management inHaiti has receivedincreased attention from the donor community since about 1998. In2000, a National Risk and Disaster Management Plan was produced which emphasized two main objectives: (i) focus on the causes of risk,to reduce the impact of disasters and (ii) reinforce response capacities at every level: central, departmental, municipal and community.
31. In line with the above strategy, the project will work with, and strengthen the capacities of, actors involved indisaster management at all levels. The second component of the project will be implementedby the DPC andthe SPGRD under the Ministryof Interior andLocalGovernment (Minist2rede 1'Znte'rieuret des Collectivite's Territoriales),with the UNDPworking closely with these institutions to provide the necessary technical assistance.

F. FINANCIAL MANAGEMENT AND DISBURSEMENT
41. Financial Management. DPC and the PL480 Management Office will be responsible for the financial management of the project. DPC will be responsible for the financial management of component 2, while the financial management o f component 1 and 3 will be the responsibility of PL 480 Management Office. The overall financial situation of the project will be consolidated by DPC following procedures that will be documented inthe Operational Manual. The findings of the financial management capacity assessmentcarried out duringproject preparationb y IDA are taken into account inthe arrangements proposed below.
42. DPC does not currently have an accounting unit since its financial management operations are handledby the accounting unit o f the Ministry of Interior. Due to the transformation of DPC into a General Directorate and the financial management responsibilities under the project, the DPC will be required to set up its own financial management system. The project will support DPC in developing a financial management system that complies with government accounting rules, satisfies the needs of the project, and allows the DPC to manage and account for resources that it will receive from external donors. Because it may take time before DPC has fully developed its internal financial management capacity, financial management will be handled at inception by a qualified accountant to be hired under the project. Hisher Terms Of Reference (TOR) will include buildingDPC staff financial management capacity. An interimfinancial management systemwill be set upfor the purpose of the project while the DPC financial management system is being developed as part of project activities.

doc.repnme: Haiti - Emergency Recovery and Disaster Management Project
doc.abstracts: The objective of the Emergency Recovery and Disaster Management Project is: (a) to support the rehabilitation of the areas affected by the recent adverse natural disasters; (b) to strengthen the country's capacity to manage natural disaster risks and better respond to emergencies resulting from adverse natural events; and (c) to reduce the vulnerability of communities through risk identification and risk mitigation activities. These objectives are consistent with one of the focal points of the Transitional Support Strategy (TSS) that outlines IDA'S strategy for Haiti over the next 24 months (FY05 and FY06). The TSS explicitly incorporates the activities already submitted to the LICUS Trust Fund, including the proposed disaster reconstruction and mitigation initiatives. The TSS, being presented to the Board together with this proposed operation, also includes in the lending program the proposed Emergency Recovery and Disaster Management Project for US$12 million equivalent. The objectives are also consistent with the overall priorities on environmental management within the Interim Cooperation Framework (ICF). The longer term objectives of the Environment Thematic Group, in which IDA is an active participant, include the development of sustainable strategies to reverse resource degradation by introducing sustainable watershed management, reforestation and measures to reduce the impact of climatic hazards.
